												Watered down, uninteresting version of King's Bounty: The Legend and its nice sequels. This started as Facebook game (which is where I tried it initially, long enough to see all the features) with microtransactions and a wait-or-pay-to-play system. Facebook login is not required to play unless you want any of the sharing features or cross-platform play with browser and mobile. Typical for this kind of game, you can expect constant "share this with your friends!" prompts and an unskippable mission to send gifts to friends, and so on.The combat system isn't as interesting as the true King's Bounty games: gone are the three hero classes and the skill trees. No mana management, you have to purchase scrolls for each spellcasting. You don't lose troops, you just pay gold to resurrect them. Units can always move their full movement and attack or fire. Units are missing some interesting abilities they have in the "real" games. Side-note: animations are also inferior-looking and don't have the wacky character of the originals.The overworld map shows its flash game origins and is a far cry from the gorgeous 3D maps of the original games. The quests are given in the usual dry facebook game style, and I haven't detected the trademark humor of KB:TL either.Only redeeming factor would be maybe the presence of a PvP option, or the simple progression system which allows you to upgrade the stats of your units, as well as a simple crafting system. Overall unless you're really interested in the social aspects or you're desperate to play this on your phone, I don't see a good reason why you'd play this instead of buying King's Bounty: The Legend. If you don't have it yet wait for the next bundle where you'll be able to get it for under 4$. (Google the "Wars of Ages" bundle for instance, should be up until mid-january 2013.)

												I love the King's Bounty games, I really do.But King's Bounty: Legions just doesn't feel right. All of the elements that made the previous games interesting were removed or tweaked to provide the most bland and generic experience possible to the player.In this game, there is no specialisation, you can spend your gold on marginal upgrades for units and spells, but cost scaling and level requirements for these upgrades is made in such a way that you can't just decide to dump all your gold into spells and rely on them. Especially since you can't learn spells, you have no mana, you have to buy scrolls, every time you use a spell you need to use a scroll.When it comes to army building, there isn't much to it unless you are willing to pay, you have access to some basic units from shops, and a few advanced units as quest rewards, but only enough to show you what these units can do and encourage you to purchase more at the real money shop. You just don't get the satisfaction of doing your best with limited resources like you did in the previous games, especially since morale mechanics and most of the units special effects were removed.Finally,  you don't have to select your battles like in the previous games, here you simply progress from one area to another with the ability to grind when you feel you aren't strong enough to take on the next challenge.The only thing that's left from the previous games is the turn-based gameplay, which just isn't enough to hold the game together without the strategic elements that the previous games had.

												Really nice-looking, sometimes clever, yet very grindy and rage-producing Pay-to-Win PvE/PvP Multiplayer King's Bounty game. It was made by the same Katauri studio, which resurrected King's Bounty title in the first place. If you familiar with some of those King's Bounty games, you'll feel yourself like at home at the start.But, but, but... the farther you go, the more you need dozens and hundreds of gaming friends on the Facebook, along you, to continue playing. Why? Firstly, friends are to send you some little, yet useful gifts, which you are need to strengthen up your army. And even with that help, you'll be grinding helplessly for missing ingredients. Secondly, some quests supposing that you're going to beat some tough enemies, which can be done only with help of friends.Why I'm talking about Facebook friends so much? For it's not the game FROM Facebook. It still runs ON Facebook, and Steam there acting just as middleman. If you don't have Facebook account or if your account is made not for gaming (like you don't want to invite hundreds of unknown people just to play along them) - you can start the game, but certainly you will not succeed in King's Bounty Legions.So don't start. It is just another grindfest, where you can't play like you want it, but need to wait until some hero's "energy" replenishes, which takes hours of real time. You can't get very far in it without supplement of at least 10-20 constantly playing facebook "friends". And you'll need hundreds of hours to achieve same things as normal game will give you in 10 hours...Mark 5/10. Time-wasting facebook grindfest game. There are so many more "free-to-play" games on the market, that are much better in terms of gameplay, even if they might not look so gorgeous as "Legions". And there are original single-player King's Bounty games, which are good. Just not mess with "Legions", it's a bad idea, that will turn you down after some time.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Having played the original for Sega Genesis, I had to try this game. Unfortunately, I was disappointed. The music wasn't bad, though not as catchy as the original, IMO. The gameplay is where the largest difference was. There is hardly a connection to the original, other than unit type and battle similarities.The methods by which troops are recruited are totally different. The basic units could be hired at the home castle, but exotic units would have to be hired from their lairs in the unexplored wilderness. Part of the challenge and fun was finding some of the more rare units during your travels. In fact, there is no exploring at all in the new game. You must defeat a predetermined number of groups of enemies before being able to advance to the next town. The new game is repetitive and slow in its progression. The battles lack the save level of dynamics and difficulty of the original. Although there are some character upgrades (equipment, etc.), you are limited to one character. The original offered 3 different characters with different strengths (income and rank, leadership, and magic). Overall, there was more freedom in the original, and everything, from the music to the exploration and battles, was more interesting. The new game lacks challenge and is very tedious. The game name "King's Bounty" shouldn't be associated with this game.

												I'm kind of saddened by this game. After the wonderful Armored Princess, Crossworlds, and North King's Bounty games, Legions comes in with not much changed graphically. What they have changed, though, is that it is now Free to Play. While I am fine with this in general, this is one of those F2P changes that feels wrong given what the game is about. In the past games, you could in theory stack your army with very powerful units (although a low number since your character level and thus "Leadership" is low) if you won early battles and knew where to recruit. Replacing this deep and interesting mechanic are paid "Starter Packs", which are not nearly as diverse or interesting as a custom crafted army, or you can buy Booster Packs or units with real money. Even this state of affairs could have been remedied if I had some early access to a wide variety of units, some of which would be the higher tier units. This is simply not the case almost 10 hours into the game. I am stuck either rolling the 2-3 strongish units (even though my Leadership could support 6-7), or having to constantly spend gold on a very sparse selection of troops to replace heavy losses from crappy troops. I mean, I shouldn't have to buy Archers as my only replenishable ranged choice. At least open it up so I can recruit any low level archer.I really hope the devs go back, do a proper update of the engine, and release a game for $20 and remove the game killing mechanics that support the F2P model. It just doesn't work for King's Bounty.You're better off buying the earlier games.

												I hate the concept of the watered-down social-networking-game as much as anyone, but it is kind of hard to complain super-hard in my opinion about "yet another King's Bounty remake," even if this is clearly the worst of the new lot due to the aforementioned factors.If nothing else, the inability to save and load as in the offline versions of the game instantly makes the gameplay interesting to me, as it means I have to put far more thought into my actions.  Even though of course it would be nice if I also had a baby dragon or valkyries to supplement combat in addition to my armies (plus, are there only scrolls?  No permanent spells?  Dumb).  Plus, some of the changes made to the basic formula of the game actually create excitement in ways the regular series does not really do--the first time I found my army in the middle of the field and enemies on both sides, I think I said "OH ♥♥♥♥ (not ♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥!  ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥)" out loud because it was so amazingly unexpected.But yes, I definitely recommend anyone who loves the King's Bounty reboot series check this out--I mean, free is free after all.  You can see where they try to gouge you with pay-to-improve transactions, but the game is also fun without them.

												I am new to the series, with that said I do enjoy this game. I've spent quite a few hours playing it and have bought some gems (I believe if you enjoy a free to play game its only right to buy some stuff). Pros-The game is fun and has a decent level of depth to the strategy and diverse content.-You can let the ai play for you, which is great when you want to watch a movie and play the game at the same time.-A multitude of deiffering monsters and soldiers to pick from.-UI is easy to navigate and understand, except for the chat system.-Units are very indepth with different abilities and counter classes.Cons-Adding friends is a pain and a chore, I made the mistake of signing up through my facebook, after trying for a few hours to find out how to add steam friends I couldn't figure it out.(To fix this I would just do what normal games do and add friends through the game, then add a facebook friend option as a secondary method).-the chat sytem is a pain, it constantly put me back into the sytem chatbox, only shows two boxes at a time which forces me to scroll to the clan chat. You can't talk in chat or clan chat while in a fight.- Again I understand the p2w model and am not against it for the most part. But to keep your legendary and even "blue" units topped off at full strength you don't have many other options which will cause you to stall out at around level 20+.(A solution I can see would be to allow players to save up items and use them along with a long cooldown to upgrade unit I.E a knight with several pieces of armor can be trained into a paladin, A swordsmen can be trained into a knight. this would give a deeper crafting system and not make players feel overly pressured into buying units with gems).- the gems don't feel scaled stuff is a little expensive like a paladin costing 28 gems, thats fine if I was only buying one every couple levels but not when I need a new paladin every level.This is just a brief review I'm sure I am missing a few points but over all I would recommend this game. If you have any questions please ask.12/20/2013*I did leave out the reason I recommended the game. It is a pretty simple reason its free, even though it is a very face bookish game (seeing as how it started tha way) the quality and level of work is pretty damn high. I doubt we will see any significant change to the game; almost never do. The bottom line is it's worth picking up for free and messing around with it as far as a tactics game goes.

												Originally featured on Kongregate.com, King's Bounty Legions borrows the popular working formula from the original King's Bounty series. To accomodate casual player and to become a MMO, NivalPublishing watered down the brutality of the original series. Instead of loosing troops and lose the ability to hire them again, the hire pool refreshes every daily. Immortal and Legendary units are rehirable at a price as they are unavaliable to replanish on the map. Unlike other MMOs on the market which requires a lot of attention to maintain a well equipted account, Legions tries to accomodate gamers who are able to commit less than an hour a day by introducing dailies which can be completed in minutes and a patrol mode.In patrol mode, the player leaves the avatar at a location and the AI does battles over time. The player can sustain losses in this mode. However, in a reasonable location, a positive income together with additional rewards makes Legions a game for busy people.Legions demostrates great promise with a good compromise between free and paid gamers. However, increasingly powerful and pricey units found on the Royal Shop (the Cash Shop on King's Bounty: Legions) greatly tilts the favor towards paid gamers in the PVP arena. (*I am trying to remember whether PVP yields any unique rewards. If it does, the game would greatly favor paying customers with a fat wallet).Fortunately, the the game redeems itself by introducing a Raid feature which pits players against various other player's teams and everything boils down to defeating the AI which controls them.What further irks me is the inability to transfer progression between different platforms. In my case, my progress from Kongregate to Steam.Still, this game is a good introduction for players who are undecided on purchasing the original King's Bounty series, a new to turn based role playing game or an online world to test their skills against other like minded gamers.

												TL;DR: Better than expected. Not a waste of time.Basically, this is a Facebook game. At least I think it's an import from FB, since you can share to your wall and it has that terrible hand-holding tutorial for the first 10 mins of gameplay. Try to power through the big dumb CLICK HERE YOU IDIOT buttons and when the game opens up a bit more it's very fun. It has Might and Magic/King's Bounty style combat, but none of the overworld parts (Which I never really cared for a ton anyway). Units are stacked and your attacks chew through each individual guy's HP until you kill the whole stack. The focus on Combat and army building over the larger scale city building and adventuring is welcome for me, others may not like that. It reminds me of playing a somewhat obscure Playstation 2 game, Gladius, since it's fight after fight with a bit of crafting and a quest between each one. I'd say give it a try, but be careful of microtransactions. Not sure how good the PvP is yet, or if there's pay-to-win, but I wouldn't be surprised. It's a fun, cut down King's Bounty experience though.

So if you don't like that kind of trash don't even bother playing the game.  It is also heavily Pay to Win typical facebook malarky.  So if you are not a fan of this then you should also stay clear.  It also has other frustrating elements of gameplay and while the tutorial explains some things it is very bla and a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  Also having to pay gold (which is in way too short supply in the game) to revive fallen units can be annoying.  Also 30 minute cooldowns to re-do a mission is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥so if some lame little character says "collect 2 of these quest items and turn it back into me!" my advice is to not turn it in so that you can actually have some fight to do over and over instead of having to wait for all the other cooldowns.Another con is it also has some of the worst starting content in a game.  You should never punish players and make it as boring as this game does in the beginning by having to basically criple your army to unlock enough areas to actually be able to progress your character.  So dumb.  As I played I kept thinking things like "man this game sucks" and "I hate this soooooo much" but I stuck it out since someone told me it will be a good game to pass the time.So why am I writing that I recommend the game?  I ended up getting a creature called the "emrald dragon" from some lucky box thing which generally gives you extremely pitiful amounts of gold (takes 2000 gold to get 1 unit that doesn't suck and you generally get 50-150 from opening the chests.)Once I gained this creature that had the ability to heal and resurect creatures around me and could do it 3 times a battle the game actually changed into something more like Kings Bounty.  I found myself playing the game around the concept of running a perfect game w/o losing any creatures each whatever I did.  And it took on an interesting form of gameplay that was actually fun.  I was suddenly playing towards the strategy of the game instead of some, no fun, facebook social nattering, invasive, pay to win ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t fest.I found myself shocked that I was actually having fun. With fb you can do 'wanted' battles for units, but the friend invite mechanic is different and so far despite adding loads of fb 'friends' I have a v. short list of invitable 'friends' to boost battle gold (I'm earlier in my fb game than the Steam one so hopefully it's just something I still need to figure out).3. Steam vs. facebook login? So far I give it to Steam for gold, but fb for units. On Steam I bought DLC for units, then used friend invites to get faster gold and level my units. 												After playing for a few weeks (finished the single player campaign which was quite short anyway), getting quite close to lvl30, and achieving a certain status in PvP ranking I could say two things about this game:1) maybe it's not exactly p2w but you definitely have to throw in 10-20 bucks just to start playing comfortably (I did, to buy some legendary creatures);2) the game itself is nice (I am a big fan of the single-player KB series) but it's plagued with various bugs and especially - it is not made for steam. Seriously. It's a facebook game, you cannot even access some of the most important features w/o facebook account AND it's not possible to connect steam and facebook - without erasing steam part of the account, no less. Until guys from Nival change their attitude I strongly recommend AGAINST paying them a dime - because chances are, the very next day you may not be able to log in again to use the in-game things you just bought. Check forums for more info...UPDATE: I've been playing this thing casually for a few months and now I could say for sure - yes, it is definitely p2w :) What's worse, though, is that the developer's greed killed all the fun. There is not much to do in the game after you beat the campaign but to PvP. Now, without upgrading your units to at least 8-10 level you're a cannon fodder. The problem is: the random generator is bugged and to reach the levels stated you will either be subjected to the long and extremely boring grind or... upgrade for real money. You want to experiment with different builds? I am sorry, but there are no way for steam players to get new creatures in-game. Recent update further decreased the chances to steal a unit in PvP (which was the only viable way for us so far) so chances to collect a stack of units without paying real money is now effectively 0. Now I woudln't mind throwing in a few bucks time after time but with one full stack costing about $30... And you need 5 of them... And don't forget, you'll have to upgrade them to make playable... Add it all up and think about it: why would someone pay a full price of a decent AAA game for a *chance* to have some fun in a typical facebook game with all of its shortcomings?..
